 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.

ALLEGATION:
On an unknown date, Case Manager 3 punched Youth A in the face as a response
to Youth A pushing Case Manager 3. This turned into a full physical altercation.
INVESTIGATION:
On 2/3/2022 I reviewed the complaint; and spoke with Complainant Z. Complainant
Z did not witness the incident. Youth B, a youth on Complainant Z’s caseload
witnessed the incident and videotaped it. Youth B sent the video to Complainant Z.
Complainant Z reported in the video one can see a staff punch a youth in the face
3

and a fight ensues. Complainant Z agreed to forward me a copy of the video
footage.
On 2/3/2022 I spoke with Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS)
Worker X related to the complaint; and I received notification from her that the
agency had suspended Case Manager 3 pending the investigation. The latter was
confirmed by the agency.
On 2/4/2022, DHHS Worker X and I interviewed Youth A, Case Manager 2, Case
Manager 3, and Administrator 1 onsite at the agency’s administrative office. Youth
Worker 4 was interviewed by us by telephone on 2/14/2022. All staff members
interviewed reported the incident happened sometime on or about 1/18/2022. All
staff members reported Youth Worker 4 called Administrator 1 to report the incident.
Additionally, all staff members denied observing any marks or bruises to Youth A;
they reported Case Manager 3 had a bruise to her eye either that day or the next
day.
Interview with Youth A:
Youth A reported she was present at a meeting with Case Manager 2 and Case
Manager 3 at the agency’s Lakewood Independent Living (IL) home. The meeting
was a discussion centered on a resident’s food being taken or eaten; and Case
Manager 3 asked Youth A questions about that. Youth A got irritated by the
questioning; did not answer; and then she and Case Manager 3 argued. Youth A
said Case Manager 3 stood in her face; was grabbing her person, her shirt; and she
does not like people being in her face. She asked Case Manager 3 to back up from
her. Case Manager 3 didn’t move back, and she pushed Case Manager 3. In turn,
Case Manager 3 punched her in the face; and she started hitting Case Manager 3
back. Youth A reported receiving a bump on her left eye from the incident. She said
the bump hurt but had no swelling or bruising. She reported the police came out, but
she was not sure who called the police. Youth A said, Case Manager 2 and Youth
Worker 4 were at the house during the incident, but neither moved to intervene until
she started hitting Case Manager 3. Youth Worker 4 grabbed Case Manager 3; and
Case Manager 2 grabbed her. Youth A reported Youth B was also present during the
incident. Youth B recorded the incident; and sent it to Administrator 1 this week,
because Administrator 1 requested it.
Youth A reported talking with Administrator 1 about the incident after it occurred but
not Case Manager 2 who was her assigned case manager. Case Manager 2 did not
follow up with her about the incident or inquire about how she was doing or her
safety. Administrator 1 spoke with her, but she did not tell Administrator 1 about the
fight or what happened during the fight. She assumed Administrator 1 knew there
was a fight, because Administrator 1 came to the house right after the fight.
Administrator 1 asked her what she wanted to do about what happened during the
incident. She did not tell Administrator 1 that she wanted to do anything about it.
4

Interview with Case Manager 2:
Case Manager 2 admitted to being present and witnessing the altercation between
Youth A and Case Manager 3. She affirmed Youth A’s reporting related to a house
meeting, its purpose and that a physical altercation ensued between Youth A and
Case Manager 3, whereby Youth A pushed Case Manager 3 and Case Manager 3 hit
Youth A. Case Manager 2 reported she and Case Manager 3 were holding the
meeting around concerns over someone eating Youth D’s food (Youth D shares the
upstairs part of this two-family flat with Youth A and Youth C. Youth B resides
downstairs). Youth A became defensive during the meeting and was yelling, calling
Case Manager 2 and Case Manager 3 dumb and stupid for thinking she ate Youth
D’s food. Youth A came from around the table to where Case Manager 3 was
standing and was yelling. Case Manager 3 told Youth A that Youth A was going to
stop disrespecting her; was going to stop talking to her like that. Youth A began
putting her hands in Case Manager 3’s face; and pushed Case Manager 3 hard. The
push caused Case Manager 3 to lose her balance, almost fall; and Case Manager 3
swung on Youth A. Case Manager 2 reported Case Manager 3 must have realized
what she had done, because Case Manager 3 grabbed and held Youth A hands and
was telling Youth A to stop hitting her. It was at this point that Case Manager 2 said
she and Youth Worker 4 intervened. Youth Worker 4 grabbed Case Manager 3.
Case Manager 2 took hold of Youth A and was taking Youth A away, but Youth A got
loose from her. Youth A came around the back of Youth Worker 4 and hit Case
Manager 3 in the face. Youth A apologized to them(staff) the next day.
Case Manager 2 reported Youth B recorded the incident, though she had advised
Youth B not to. She said, Youth B was recording and verbally egging Youth A on.
Youth B was telling Youth A to “whip the B’s ass”. Case Manager 2 reported seeing
the video footage but reported what she saw on the footage was only Case Manager
3 hitting Youth A, not Youth A pushing and hitting Case Manager 3.
Interview with Case Manager 3
Case Manager 3 affirmed basically what was reported by Case Manager 2 related to
the house meeting, Youth A’s behaviors and actions during the incident. She said
Youth A was cursing, calling them dumb “mother fuckers”. Youth A got into her face;
Youth A used Youth A’s finger and poked her on the forehand twice. She asked
Youth A to get out of her face three times. She said, “before I knew it, I did hit her”.
Then she grabbed Youth A and put Youth A into a restraint so Youth A couldn’t hit
her again. She reported her hit on Youth A was “like a slap on the face, not a punch”.
She said, Youth A had pushed her, knocked her off her feet and she could have fell.
She said, “that push affected me”. She said when she grabbed Youth A, Youth
Worker 4 and Case Manager 2 separated her and Youth A. Youth Worker 4 held her
and was telling her to calm down. She said, Case Manager 2 grabbed Youth A, but
Youth A broke loose from Case Manager 2. Youth A ran and hit her in the face, near
her forehead, just over the left eye. She said, Youth Worker 4 continued to tell her to
calm down. She said, “I wanted to attack her. I was angry”. She admitted that before
the physical incident between she and Youth A, Youth Worker 4, got up and offered
5

to assist, but she told him “We’re good”. She said that was because she thought they
were, that she was handling the situation.
Case Manager 3 denied going after Youth A when Youth A came around Youth
Worker 4 and hit her. She reported Youth Worker 4 held her and was getting her
calmed down. She reported she “had never been hit by a kid” before, and she was
taken back by it. She said she would not do anything to hurt a child; she wants to
open a home for children.
Interview with Administrator 1:
Administrator 1 affirmed being contacted by Youth Worker 4 about the incident on the
day of the incident. Additionally, that she spoke with Youth A and inquired about what
happened and whether Youth A needed to go to the hospital. Youth A informed her,
Youth A and Case Manager 3 had a fight and Case Manager 2 and Youth Worker 4
broke it up. Youth A admitted to Administrator 1 that Case Manager 3 hit her, but
denied she was punched or slapped by Case Manager 3. Youth A said, no to
needing to go to the hospital for any medical attention. Administrator 1 told Youth A
Administrator 1 needed to call Centralize Intake about the incident and Youth A did
not want her to. Youth A said she was in the wrong; that she was mad and cursed
Case Manager 3 because the staff was accusing her of taking Youth D’s food. Youth
A said she got in Case Manager 3’s face and pushed Case Manager 3.
Administrator 1 reported she also spoke with Case Manager 3 on the day of the
incident. Case Manager 3 said she was not trying to hurt Youth A; that Youth A
never would have gone as far as Youth A had if Youth B had not been egging Youth
A on. Administrator 1 had Case Manager 3 and Youth A “to talk it out”. At that point
Administrator 1 thought the matter was resolved.
Interview with Youth Worker 4:
Youth Worker 4 reported the incident was about Youth A disrespecting the staff. He
said he was in the other room and could hear what was being said. Youth A was
referring to staff as “Bitches”. Youth A got up and put her hand in Case Manager 3’s
face; and Case Manager 3 asked Youth A to get her hand out her face. Youth
Worker 4 said, he got up and got in between the youth and case manager, because
he did not know what either’s intentions were. At that point Case Manager 3 told him
“I got this”. Case Manager 3 grabbed Youth A’s hands, then let them go. Thereon,
Youth Worker 4 described the push and what happened after the push as Case
Manager 2 had. He said, Case Manager 3 may have hit Youth A in the chest/head
area. Case Manager 3 also grabbed and tried to restraint Youth A. He grabbed Case
Manager 3 but had to let Case Manager 3 go when Youth A hit him in the back of the
head. He said, Youth A was the aggressor. He said, he took Case Manager 3 into
the other room to talk with her. He denied that Case Manager 3 ever tried to go after
Youth A after he and Case Manager 2 separated the two. He said, Youth D was
also in the house, but he was not sure whether Youth D witnessed any of the
incident. Youth Worker 4 was not aware of any other incident between Youth A and
Case Manager 3.
6

Youth Worker 4 reported the police did not come to the home. He did call the police,
he called Administrator 1 about the incident. Administrator 1 did not instruct him to
call the police or Centralized Intake. Nor did Administrator 1 say she would attend to
those contacts. Administrator 1 advised him to write an incident report, which he did
on the day of the incident. Administrator 1 and Case Manager 3 returned to the
home, and had a meeting with Youth A, later that day. He was not aware of what
occurred in that meeting.
On 2/14/2022 I spoke with Youth A’s purchase of service worker, DHHS-Foster Care
Worker (FCW) X0. DHHS- FCW X0 reported being aware of the incident. She
received incident reports from the agency about the matter sometime on or about
1/22/2022. She had no further information about the matter.
On 3/3/2022, a second DHHS Worker, DHHS Worker XX and I interviewed Youth B
onsite at the Juvenile Detention Facility. Youth B affirmed taking the video of the
incident. She reported information similar to Youth A, Case Manager 2, and Case
Manager 3 related to the incident. She described the physical action by Case
Manager 3 as Case Manager 3 punching Youth A and putting Youth A into a head
lock. She said no one called the police. She admitted to filming the video of the
incident and sending it to her probation worker and DHHS worker.
Reviewed:
 Incident report statements from Youth Worker 4, Case Manager 2, Case
Manager 3, and Administrator 1, all typed and dated 1/18/2022, which:
 Was a version of basically what each reported when they were
interviewed.
 All indicated management was contacted about the incident; and all
except, Case Manager 3 indicating the police were not contacted.
 All indicated Youth A was cursing; and or that Youth A made a
statement about being able to say “What the Fuck” she wants because
she is grown.
 All indicated Youth A pushed Case Manager 3 and Case Manager 3
hit Youth A.
 Video footage received from Complainant Z which showed the following
 The camera trying to focus, and Youth A being heard saying you sound
stupid; and Case Manager 3 responding but I cannot tell what that
response was.
 Youth A and Case Manager 3 standing facing each other with some
space between them, that quickly closed as the incident advanced
onward.
 Youth A telling Case Manager 3 to “Shut the fuck up”; and Case Manager
3 responded, with “Make me”.
7

 Youth A put her hand up toward Case Manager 3’s face twice. On the
second time that Youth A did that, Case Manager 3 slapped Youth A’s
hand down/away.
 Case Manager 3 put her hand up toward Youth A and stepped closer to
Youth A, directly in her face. Case Manager 3 grabbed Youth A’s arms.
Case Manager 3 held Youth A’s arms up toward Youth A’s chest for a few
moments, pulled on Youth A’s shirt, let go of Youth A, and pushed or hit
Youth A’s arm backward.
 Youth A and Case Manager 3 continued facing each other, and Youth A
stating for Case Manager 3 to get back; that, “it’s COVID, it’s COVID”.
Case Manager 3 responded, by telling Youth A that she had asked Youth
A not to come in her face and that “I promise you, I promise” (promised
what was not stated). Case Manager 3 stated “you’re in arm’s length little
girl and don’t play with me, don’t play with me”. Case Manager 3 pushed
Youth A arm backward, slightly.
 Youth A asked Case Manager 3 to back up from her. Case Manager 3
stated “I’m not backing up Shit, now; I’m not backing up shit”. Case
Manager 3 told Youth A that she had asked Youth A three times to get
out her face/ to not get in her face.
 Youth A pushed Case Manager 3 in the chest area and stated, “back up
girl,”; and Case Manager 3 punched Youth A with her fist in the face,
grabbed Youth A around the neck and held Youth A in a headlock.
 Youth Worker 4 and Case Manager 2 intervened. Youth Worker 4 got in
between the youth and case worker; and Case Manager 2 grabbed Youth
A.
 Youth A and Case Manager 3 continued trying to get at each other during
Youth Worker 4’s and Case Manager 2’s intervention. Case Manager 3
hit across Youth Worker 4 striking at Youth A’s body area.
 Case Manager 2 appeared to struggle to get Youth A to the living room.
Youth Worker 4 was holding Case Manager 3 in the dining room.
 Youth A came from the living room and hit Case Manager 3; and Youth
Worker 4 grabbed Youth A and returned her to living room’s couch area.
During this time Case Manager 3 came from dining room and tried to get
to Youth A. Youth Worker 4 grabbed Case Manager 3; and Case
Manager 3 continued to try to break free from Youth Worker 4 to go after
Youth A.
 Youth B is heard during the physical altercation laughing, stating “All shit”;
that she was “teeted up”, asking other if they are teeted up; and reporting
that she was getting it all on tape.
 As Youth Worker 4 walked Case Manager B out the room, the house; and
Youth D was seen briefly, as the youth worker and case manager went
pass.
8

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12206 Staff qualifications
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has
ongoing contact with children or parents to be a person
who has the ability, experience, education, and training to
perform the duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: Youth A, Case Manager 2, Youth Worker 4, Youth B, as well as
Case Manager 3 all reported Case Manager 3, hit or punched
Youth A.
Case Manager 3 admitted to being angry and wanting to attack
Youth A. She denied attacking, punching, or trying to go after
Youth A once she and Youth A were separated.
The video footage showed:
 Case Manager 3 hit Youth A’s hand down when Youth
A put her hand up toward Case Manager 3’s face.
 Case Manager 3 grabbed Youth A arms, and held
them; pulled on Youth A’s shirt, and slightly pushed
Youth A’s arm backward.
 Case Manager 3 spoke loudly/ not in a calming tone,
was antagonistic, and unprofessional during her
interaction with Youth A. Case Manager 3 stepped
closer into Youth A’s personal space while telling
Youth A she had asked Youth A not to invade her own
personal space. Case Manager 3 told Youth A to
make her when Youth A asked her to move out her
personal space.
 Case Manager 3 cursed at Youth A, told Youth A she
was not “Backing Up Shit”, twice.
9

 Case Manager 3 punched Youth A in the face with
Case Manager 3’s fist. She also grabbed Youth A
around the neck and held Youth A in a headlock.
 When Youth Worker 4 and Case Manager 2
intervened to break up the altercation, Case Manager
3 did not stop or walk away. She continued to try to go
after Youth A. She hit across Youth Worker 4 to strike
at Youth A.
 After Youth A broke free and hit Case Manager 3
again, Case Manager 3 went after Youth A, when at
that point Youth A was being taken away from her.
This action by Case Manager 3 caused Youth Worker
4 to grab Case Manager 4 again; and Case Manager
3 tried to break free of Youth Worker 4 to advance
toward Youth A.
Case Manager 3 did not try to deescalate the incident. Her
verbal and physical actions escalated the incident with an
escalated Youth A. Case Manager 3’s cursing at and putting
her hands on Youth A; as well as her trying to restraint Youth A,
punching Youth A in the face, and putting Youth A in a
chokehold all illustrate Case Manager 3 did not have the ability,
experience, education, and training to perform the duties
assigned.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
(1) During the investigation it was revealed the agency did not report the staff/resident
physical altercation; and Case Manager 3 hitting Youth A to Centralized Intake.
DHHS Worker X and I interviewed Case Manager 2, Case Manager 3, and
Administrator 1 onsite on 2/4/2022. Youth Worker 4 was interviewed by us by telephone
on 2/14/2022. All four staff members reported that they did not report the incident of
Youth A being hit/ being in a physical altercation with Case Manager 3 to children
services.
Case Manager 2 acknowledged knowing she is a mandated reporter; but rationalized
not doing so. She said things were blown out of proportion. Youth A was being loud
aggressive, and the incident was being egged on by Youth B. Additionally that Case
Manager 3 apologized.
Case Manager 3 reported not knowing they were mandated to report the incident to
Centralized Intake.
10

Youth Worker 4 reported he was not advised by Administrator 1 to call Centralized
Intake.
Administrator 1 acknowledged Youth A admitted that Case Manager 3 hit her, but Youth
A denied she was punched or slapped by Case Manager 3. Administrator 1 reported
advising Youth A that Administrator 1 needed to call the incident in to Centralized
Intake. Administrator 1 reported the following reasons as to why she did not call
Centralized Intake. Youth A did not want her to; Youth A took responsibility for the
incident, said she was wrong for getting in Case Manager 3’s face; and pushing Case
Manager 3, when Case Manager 3 kept trying to talk with her; Youth A and Case
Manager 3 had a good relationship; Case Manager 3 reported she was not trying to
hurt Youth A; the two talked it out and Administrator 1 felt the matter was resolved.
Additionally, Administrator 1 did not know the severity of the incident until she saw the
video that Youth B’s probation officer sent to her on 1/31/2022. At that latter date
Administrator 1 suspended Case Manager 3. She reported suspending Case Manager
3 from her job pending the complaint investigation, due to Case Manager 3 restraining
and hitting Youth A. She denied past disciplinary actions for Case Manager 3. She
stated Case Manager 3 is a good employee who does well with the children.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12214 Compliance with 1975 PA 238.
An agency shall develop a written plan and implement the plan
to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621, and
known as the child protection law.
ANALYSIS: Youth A affirmed to Administrator 1 Case Manager 3 hit her.
Case Manager 2, Youth Worker 4, as well as Case Manager 3
also affirmed the physical altercation between Youth A and
Case Manager 3 and that Youth A was hit by Case Manager 3
during the physical altercation. All the stated staff members
reported they did not report the incident to children services, or
the police with respect to possible maltreatment of Youth A.
The agency failed to report the physical assault on Youth A by a
staff member, as required by the rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
(2) During the investigation it was revealed Case Manager 3 restrained or tried to
restrain Youth A. Restraining a youth is not a part of the agency’s behavioral
management plan.
DHHS Worker X and I interviewed, Case Manager 2, Case Manager 3, and
Administrator 1 onsite on 2/4/2022. Youth Worker 4 was interviewed by us by
11

telephone on 2/14/2022. Administrator 1 did not witness the incident; Case Manager 3’s
action was reported to her.
Case Manager 2 reported Case Manager 3 grabbed Youth A and was holding her.
Youth Worker 4 reported Case Manager 3 grabbed Youth A and tried to restrain Youth
A.
Case Manager 3 reported she grabbed Youth A’s arms during the incident and was
restraining Youth A. She reported the agency does not have a policy authorizing the use
of restraints. She reported she is to call the police if the youth is in a physical
altercation; but the agency training does not advise her what to do if she as a staff is
attacked by a youth. She never envisioned such happening. She reported reacting in
the moment; and her restraining Youth A was a reflect. She learned how to restrain via
the Oak Park Police Department in 2011. No updated restraint training was reported by
her. She reported no prior training on de-escalation, nor could she recall conflict
resolution training.
Administrator 1 reported they do not have a restraint policy. She stated “We don’t
restrain. We call the police.” She indicated that prior to any training on de-escalation
the staff are advised to retreat, not to get into a physical altercation.
Reviewed
 A copy of the agency’s Discipline Policy which indicated:
 Staff may utilize the following behavior management techniques:
 Positive Reinforcement.
 Trauma Informed Care Approach.
 Crisis Intervention.
 Prohibited approaches. The following techniques are prohibited to manage
a resident in any type of distress (emotionally, mentally, or physically):
 (1). Corporal punishment, restraining youth, or any kind of
punishment inflicted on the body.
 (2). Confinement in an area such as a closet, or locked room.
 (3). Withholding food, clothing, rest, toilet use, or entrance to the
residence.
 (4). Mental or emotional cruelty.
 (5). Verbal abuse, threats, or derogatory remarks.
 (6). Prohibiting visits or communication with a child’s foster family.
 (7). Denial of necessary educational, medical, counseling, or social
work services.
 Training record documentation for Case Manager 2(date of hire 9/24/2020;
parttime- 11/3/2021 fulltime), Case Manager 3(Date of hire 11/17/2019), and
Youth Worker 4(Date of hire 1/2/2017) which showed each of these three-
members had verbal de-escalation training on 1/15/2022. A date each had
completed mandated reporting and crisis intervention was not indicated on each
staff member’s training sheet. Administrator 1 reported this was training for the
year and if a date was not indicated the training had not occurred yet.
12

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(1). An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for the independent living services provided.
ANALYSIS: Case Manager 3 did not adhere to the agency’s discipline policy
which prohibited the use of restraints, verbal abuse, and
derogatory remarks.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
(3). During the investigation it was revealed the agency did not adequately safety plan
for Youth A after the physical altercation with Case Manager 3.
DHHS Worker X and I interviewed, Youth A Case Manager 2, Case Manager 3, and
Administrator 1 onsite on 2/4/2022. Youth Worker 4 was interviewed by us by
telephone on 2/14/2022. Youth A, Case Manager 2, Case Manager 3, and Youth
Worker 4 all reported there was physical altercation and or fight between Youth A and
Case Manager 3 on or about 1/18/2022. That Case Manager 3 hit or punched Youth A
on the day of the incident. This specific information was reported to Administrator 1 on
the same date.
Youth A reported Case Manager 2 to be her foster care worker. She reported Case
Manager 2 did not speak with her after the incident to inquire how she was doing.
Case Manager 2 reported she did not do safety planning with Youth A after the incident.
She reported things were blown out of proportion. She reported when Youth A called to
apologize, she assumed the matter was over; and that Case Manager 3 also apologized
